title: Garfield Sobers cries: West Indies legend brought to tears | The
text:
SIR Garfield Sobers is one of cricket’s most celebrated players, someone whose skill and enterprise with bat and ball brought joy to millions across the world, and especially in the West Indies.
But this week the legendary all-rounder felt only sorrow.
In an emotional press conference ahead of the second ‘Sobers-Tissera’ Trophy Test against Sri Lanka, Sobers was on the brink of crying as he lamented the current plight of West Indies cricket.
He launched a stinging barb at the modern group of Caribbean players, many of whom are not playing Test cricket but continue to ply their trades in Twenty20 leagues in India, Australia and the UK.
West Indies batsman Marlon Samuels (L) walks past Sir Garfield Sobers. Source: AFP
Sobers effectively accused them of only playing for themselves.
“My whole obligation was to West Indies cricket,” Sobers said. “As I have always said, I have never made a run for me. Records meant nothing. The team was important.
“I don’t think we have that kind of person in West Indies cricket anymore, who’s quite prepared to play and to give everything to their country. And that hurts.”
As Sobers spoke of the hurt, tears began to well in his eyes and his voice wavered, giving a clear indication of just how painful it is for one of the giants of the game to see his once great cricketing nation continue to struggle on the world stage.
“Until we can get people who are willing to play for West Indies in the right way, I think that we’re going to be struggling for a long time.”
